At video time 18:20, when talking about say  matrix   transposes, I would like to point out to the following important fact, that is: the apostrophe  alone determines the conjugate transpose, which is completely different from the transpose. To determine the transpose of say matrix M , MATLAB does it as  M.' (M followed by dot followed by apostrophe). Either one is legitimate when dealing with  vectors or/and matrices containing solely real numbers. Care should be exercised when dealing with complex numbers. For example, when M=[2  -3], M'=M.'=[2 ; -3] . However if  M=[-3+4i  -3-4i], M'=[-3-4i ; -3+4i] and M.'=[-3+4i ; -3-4i]. Apart from that, an excellent video. Thank you.

An absolutely useless video! It seems that you have no idea what people working in science really need. For example, I have a simple task: to define an NxN matrix with elements A_{ij}=exp(-i^2-j^2). In any other language I do this in a very simple way, e.g. "do i=1,N do j=1,N A[i,j]=exp(-i^2-j^2) end do end do". In this video you just play with numbers and forms of matrixes, which may be interesting for kindergarten children, but do not report anything useful for people working in science. And the whole "Mathematica Help" is constructed in a similar way - a lot of rather trivial instructions but nothing useful that would help me to solve my real problems!

What does that note mean at the bottom right of the board at time 38:55? It looks like AeR^(mxn).

This is just a way to say that the matrix A is an element of the set of all m-by-n real numbered matrices (as opposed to complex numbered matrices).  This is just saying that A is an m-by-n matrix of real numbers.

Very good point, unfortunately this video was filmed using a slightly older version of Matlab.  Matlab comes out with new versions every 6 months and usually they are small changes but as you can see, some of the updates change the UI.  There are typically no breaking changes in terms of code/syntax but keep your eye out in the future.  I will try to mention areas where there might be discrepancies in the future.

I am so glad to have these introductory videos as reference for AE501. Unlike a typical classroom lecture, I can rewind the video if I miss a portion as follow along at my own pace. That being said, I have been following along in my own Mathematica notebook for these videos and I am taken back by the speed at which you can efficiently input script into both Mathematica and MATLAB, while simultaneously reserving enough processing power to give a detailed lecture. I frequently have to back up 10 or 15 seconds and re-watch a section because I was too focused on inputting script. This format is great for that, but if this were a live classroom lecture and I had no ability to rewind, I would miss a LOT of material in trying to keep up in my own file.

Question:
With some plotting detail functions in Mathematica, pressing enter when the autofill appears will generate an arrow on its own. However sometimes I noticed you need to enter a -> (arrow) manually in order to obtain the correct syntax for the function to work. Why does Mathematica generate the arrow automatically for some functions, but other times you need to create one manually?

Seth, good question, I'm still not fully familiar with when Mathematica will auto-complete things like arrows for you.  For the arrow, if you just try to draw the arrow with ASCII art (type '-' then '>'), the next time you hit spacebar, Mathematica will replace it with the arrow symbol.  I'll show some other tricks in future videos.  Let me know if you run into any other interesting behavior.

In pure math, the measure of an angle normally starts from the x-positive direction, or East, and increases counterclockwise, and this is called the East-Counterclockwise Convention, and is achieved by atan2(y, x). The order of x and y, however, can be reversed intentionally, or negative sign be added, to achieve different purposes. For instance, atan2(x, y) follows the North-Clockwise Convention, and atan2(-x, -y) follows the South-Clockwise Convention, and these two conventions are often used in the solar energy industry as discussed here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_azimuth_angle#A_formula_based_on_the_subsolar_point_and_the_%7F'%22%60UNIQ--postMath-00000009-QINU%60%22'%7F_function

AE 501 Hi Professor Lum, at time 1:27:05 we assume that S is positive. I am confused on why we can make this assumption and what would happen if it were not positive, would the laplace transform then not be possible since it no longer goes to 0 as t goes to infinity? 

Also, what does it mean for s to be positive? does this mean that both real and imaginary components must be positive?

Thank you

The short answer for what s represents, is complex frequency.  It is a mixture of a real component that corresponds to exponential decay, and  complex component that corresponds to sinusoidal oscillation.  The Laplace transform scans the original function for a spectrum of amplitudes as a function of all values of s with a positive real component, and any imaginary component.

Since s being negative would correspond to exponential growth, rather than exponential decay, negative values of s generally aren't applicable to reality.  For exponential terms with positive poles, you get the explosion of exponential growth, which is considered unstable.

There is the bilateral Laplace transform, that considers s being negative.  I'll leave it to you to search for more about it.

why does sF(s) should have poles on the left half of the real imaginary plane can anyone please explain

I think that it is related to the 'stability', we can say the system is stable when all its poles are on the LHP, and when the system is such, its value in the permanent regime will be constants so we can calculate the final value. But when we have at least one pole on the RHP the system will be unstable and the curve in the permanent regime will go to infinity.

AE501: At time-stamp 24:30 it took me a second to figure out whether the result we were talking about was in the time domain or laplace domain. Referring back to the FVT, looks like we're in the time domain. i.e. x(t) not X(s). Good stuff. Seems powerful, though I could see this getting quickly out of hand with functions that are significantly more complex than a step function. Seems useful in applications where you're seeking the long term response, maybe like determining whether or not aircraft flutter will dampen out or not..? However for many applications I can think of, the dynamic/transient response on its way to steady state seems like the critical information.

Seth, you are absolutely correct, most of the time we want the transient/total response for the reasons you mention.  The FVT is often used as a quick check to ensure that your transient solution agrees with FVT.

AE 501:

Hey Chris! One of my favorite things about seeing the videos arranged in this way (and I guess binging them like I have been) is how clear the throughline is between what we want to do and how to do it.

Its clear to see that:
1. We want to solve for a function that gives us the position of something at a time (x(t))
2. We have a model of the behavior of our system, but it is a multi-order differential equation, and so a pain to solve traditionally.
3. So, we are going to do the following:
     a. Put it in the laplace domain.
     b. Solve for the function there.
     c. Partially expand our result
     d. Take the inverse laplace. 

And boom. You have your position at a given time. Or, if you don't feel like taking an inverse laplace, you can check if you can predict a study state with the FTV.

I know what I said is kind of obvious, but for some reason this whole process wasn't as clear for me when I first learned it in undergrad. Thanks for helping connect all the dots now!
Bryan, thanks for the clearly laid out observations.  I'm glad this presentation order makes sense.  On that note, if there is ever anything that you notice that can be improved, please let me know!

AE 501: When you use defined the inputs (5:00 mins) and created the constant block to identify x, is the constant value 3 that was assigned x(0)?
No, these are simply static inputs/signals, not initial conditions.  In other words, these are signals that do not change over the duration of the simulation.
Great intro. Looks powerful. Question, how do you input a series of numbers for example? (AE501)
Can you elaborate what do you mean by 'series of numbers'?  Do you mean if one of the signals is a vector instead of a scalar signal?
@ChristopherLum like a series of inputs from 1 to 10 in 0.1 increments to generate a series of points in order to plot a graph.

@glopez99 Ah, I see.  Simulink automatically advances time so you can make plots of any signal vs. time.  Note that the time steps are not necessarily evenly spaced.  We can talk more about this later if you'd like.

What is the purpose of the transfer function if it can't incorporate initial conditions? Are there some situations where it's much easier to evaluate than the other approaches?

AE501:
Hi Professor, I am having trouble with adjusting the x-axis time from the Matlab code after plotting the Simulink model. The plot is set to read "Signal.Values.Time" which is set to 10 seconds. How would I go about changing that value? Do I adjust it in Matlab or Simulink? -Natalia Ermolaeva

for those who are using R2021b some tweaks are to be made as described below
11:42 you will see an extra variable (probably named ans) in your workspace once 'sim('PendulumModel.slx')' command is executed.
13:55 Now after that when you create an outport(yout) in simulink and run the code, you wont see any other variable getting added to your workspace.
that is because the 'yout' variable will be created under the variable that was previously generated(probably named ans). 

Due to this you wont get the output you are expecting, to get the appropriate output just change code line, at
15:17 thetasignal = yout.getElement('theta');        to   thetasingal = ans.yout.getElement('theta');

also to check the yout variable in command prompt , 
14:05 type 'ans.yout'+enter

19:31 to get signal dimensions
go to debug  ------>  information overlays ------->signals------->signal dimensions

23:58 'simX' & 30:38 'logsout' is similar variable to 'yout'. Change the code in similar way.

Hi one QST plise

Do you have video show Matlab/Simulink co-simulation. For example: If the Matlab runs a scenario from 0 to 10 sec at time-step t0. At each t0 Matlab-time-step, Matlab generates data D that needs to be sent in the Simulink model. The Simulink model is also runs from 0 to 10 sec, but 1) it runs at t1 Simulink-time-step, 2) at each t0 time-interval it gets D data from Matlab, 3) it  outputs data, called outData (initial outData=0) at each t2 time-interval. So both Matlab code and Simulink model run together to finish from 0 to 10 seconds. In addition, the Simulink model needs to use all the D data from beginning to the latest one in order to run at each t1 Simulink-time-step.

I think there is a misunderstanding of zeta values; i'll clear up: 
For a damping system without external force zeta=0  refers to a critically damped system 
As a force is applied to a system, zeta >1/sqrt(2) refers to the case for which there will be no resonance of the system

AE501: Very well explained! Any extra tips for choosing how many states you want in your space matrix when your states are just derivatives of the same function? I assume it's partly dependent on how accurate want in your model to be and if there are any forces dependent on those states?

If you have an nth order ODE in traditional form, you'll actually need exactly n states in your state space representation.  I think what you are getting at is more of a modeling question of asking how what order system do you want to try and model with the ODE (for example do you only have rigid body modes on your aircraft or do you introduce states to keep track of things like fuel slosh, wing bending, etc.).  We'll dig into this in AE512.

AE501 Very abstract, but it began to make sense when I thought of the state-space as a mathematical representation of the "process" in a control loop... Is that the correct way of thinking of it?

Thomas, yes that is exactly correct.  The process or plant of a control system can easily be described using a state space representation.  That being said, any linear dynamic system can be represented as a state space system.

AE501: This lecture is a great intro to the topic which I very much needed to review. The clear breakdown of the steps to derive these equations makes these problems seem less intimidating despite how high the nth order can be.

AE501: Thanks for another intuitive lecture. Question. When we solve ODE's for the state, that's describing how the system itself behaves? whereas, if we want to know outputs that depend on the state (i.e. sensor readings), we would have to be given separate y(t) equations? I had always been confused when to use state-space representations vs. when not to because when I first learned ODEs, the term "output" seemed to be used to describe both the system response (state) and outputs dependent on the state.

Aimee, correct, the system state is all the information needed to predict the future behavior of the system.  For an aircraft, this might include things like airspeed, AoA, etc.  However, if you don't have sensors to measure all these, then the outputs might be a different set of signals that are derived from the states.  For example you might have an airspeed sensor that measures airspeed but no AoA vane to directly measure AoA

AE 501: Hi Professor Lum, for the state vector on the electro-magnet experiment you've chosen z(t) and z'(t), so position and velocity. 

I was expecting the same for the  Two Tank Hydraulic System, but you've chosen for the state vector, position h1(t) and position h2(t) (instead of velocity).

Hi Marcos, the choice of state vector is often dictated by the system.  In the case of the MBL, you need both position and velocity because the EOMs are a single, 2nd order ODE.   For the hydraulic system, it is actually two, first order ODEs so you need different information to predict the evolution of the system.

AE501: for the magnetic force, is you just use a lookup table instead of an analytic function, does that mean you can't solve the system for the rate of change of magnetic force Fm'(t) but only the position and the rate of change of that?

Beni, good question.  Even with a lookup table, you can still find the derivatives of the states, you just apply the lookup table and plug it into the equations for xdot.  That being said, the lookup table is by definition nonlinear so you can't make predictions of the system behavior.

I don't use Matlab or Mathematica.  I use Mathcad.  Mathcad does not have an expm() function like Matlab so I had to write my own which is basically using the original definition.   This is necessary for calculating the discrete A and B matrices.     I just calculate from n =0 to 7.   This is possible because I really need to do expm(A*delta_t).   The delta_t makes all the elements small so they don't "blow up"  Too much time was wasted with the Ps.   The Ps are not necessary. 

I always have my  worksheets done ahead of time so I don't waste time writing them in a video.   This video should be about 10 minutes.  I scrubbed through it.
AE501- Why is the ONLY diagonal case of the matrix so critical for Matrix EXP?
Good question, we'll answer this exact question when we look at the Modal Method for computing the matrix exponential as well as how to analytically solve these systems of equations.
This is nice. See what happens when A = -transpose(A) and trace(A) = 0?  exp(A) is a rotation!
There's a nice Wikipedia page, "Derivative_of_the_exponential_map", which has the derivative of exp(A(t)).
Another great video!

AE501 Why would non-distinct eigenvalues prevent us from calculating the matrix exponential?

This gets into something called 'Jordan Form' of a matrix.  You can still calculate the matrix exponential but the matrix may not be diagonoalizable therefore requiring modifications to the modal method.

AE501 - 
Professor Lum, 
First of all, great video. Helps explains the mathematical theory behind generating 3D plots. I never understood what Matlab was doing behind the scenes as you plug in equations/functions, so this video helps demystify the topic. I think my biggest takeaway will be understanding that Matlab is actually using the mesh *product* of x and y to evaluate f(x,y). I assume this evaluation can be extended to 3D scalar functions, it just becomes more difficult to actually visualize.

Karina, exactly, you can absolutely apply this to higher dimensional function but as you mention, it is hard to visualize.  Usually you'll have to hold several other variables constant and then plot how the remaining 2 vary (using the same techniques we applied here).

When using the Plot3D command with a function being defined in a separate Mathematica row, I am getting an error that the tag list is protected. The y variable is showing up in blue as undefined while the x variable is showing up in black as defined. How would I define the function in a separate row? - Natalia Ermolaeva
The tag list protected error usually means you are trying to overwrite a variable that you've previously defined.  Perhaps try 'Clear[variablename]' and then try again.

Thank you for this fantastic lecture on the applied side of the Jacobian. It's great to see the sensitivity interpretation laid out so clearly.

I've always been fascinated by its formal structure as a type of **"outer product"** between two fundamental mathematical objects:
1.  The function (or vector of functions) \( \mathbf{F}: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m \)
2.  The vector of partial derivative operators \( \nabla = \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial x_1}, \ldots, \frac{\partial}{\partial x_n} \right) \)

Their "product" \( J = \nabla \otimes \mathbf{F} \) yields a matrix ( (1,1) tensor) whose components \( J_{ij} = \frac{\partial F_i}{\partial x_j} \) precisely measure the tangency of the function \( \mathbf{F} \) to the coordinate axes defined by our partial derivatives. It's the natural object that tells us how the output space is stretched and rotated by the map \( \mathbf{F} \) which is why the determinate of the Jacobian is a pushforward. 

This geometric view connects beautifully to your point about total sensitivity since `J_ij = ‚àÇF_i/‚àÇx_j` precisely measure how the function stretches, shears, and rotates the coordinate axes‚Äîquantifying the 'sensitivity' or 'tangency' you described, but in the language of differential geometry and tensor analysis. This perspective unifies the calculus and linear algebra behind it beautifully."

- Purdue Resident Delinquent

But why should we multiply the two rates, and not, say, add them together? IMO this part is the hardest to explain

I think it should be seen as leverage effects in a chain. If I have two levers connected and equal, a small amplitude variation on the first lever will be reproduced with the same amplitude at the end of the second lever. Depending on the length of the levers, the amplitude of the variation can be multiplied or reduced (demultiplied), allowing for adjustments in the range of movements

Of course, the different lever arm ratios represent the rates of variation. For example, a 1:2 ratio linked to another 1:2 will give an amplitude of 1:4.
A 1:1 ratio linked to another 1:1 will give an amplitude of 1.A 3:1 ratio linked to a 2:1 will give an amplitude of 6:1.
I‚Äôve never seen the decomposition approach. It makes deeper sense than memorizing the chain rule!

AE501: Hi Professor Lum, I remember the problems we worked through previously with the ODE's that were linear and non-linear and observing how they behaved differently. Orkida, that is a good observation but unfortunately it has hard to predict behavior for those types of problem.  This is especially true when we work with PDEs rather than ODEs as they can be much more complicated.  You may need to deal with them on a case-by-case basis.

This was such a needlessly complicated way to derive the 1D Wave Equation. You could have simply taken the sum of both vertical tension components and tended the sum towards the limit of delta(x) -> 0. You'd get the formal definition of a partial derivative to describe tension and be able to skip 10 minutes of convoluted trigonometry. Missing stuff like this demonstrates a lack of actual understanding to the laws you're applying - you've clearly just blunt force memorized the most complicated explanation from a Real Analysis textbook.

why is tension constant? :)
That's a simplifying assumption.
So if slopes are small is an assumption: that means that du/dx~0. Wouldn't that make d2u/dx2 even more 0? Why would we remove du/dx from the equation but not it's second partial w/r/to x?

Look at a sinusoidal wave u(x)=sin(kx). du/dx=kcos(kx), d2u/dx2=-k^2sin(kx), i.e. if k>1, then the second derivative is numerically larger than the first. The physical interpretation is that the string is long compared to the wavelength of the waves propagating on it.

@ChristopherLum I have this same question and watching the whole video didn't resolve it.

@issarice The best way to formalize this step is by considering the taylor series of sine and cosine and retain only the lowest order terms in the angle. For the cosine is one and for cosine is the angle itself.

The remaning terms are negligible comparing to these ones. For cosine we would have 1 + (small_angle^2 )/2 + ... , for sine small_angle. Now notice that small_angle^2  is much smaller than small_angle. like 0.001^2 = 0.000001 <<0.001

this proof, as well as others, is making a lot of assumptions that I don't really like. Here's one that you make at 15:45 - mass = density * deltaX. If the PQ segment were horizontal, that would be true, but it's not

deltaX in my opinion should be written as dx at first place, implying that it's a difference that is infinitesimally small. In that case you can make an "infinitely correct" approximation by claiming that it's horizontal in given interval (dx). This is what calculus is all about.

Nice derivation. I have a question though.You end up with a proportionality between the second derivatives with respect to time and space. Your approach is geometrical and you are looking for the wave equation as an expression for the amplitude. On the other hand if you derive the Schrodinger equation (also a wave equation) and in this case you are also modeling the amplitude of a wave albeit with special interpretations. Instead of a geometric approach, the Schrodinger  equation derives from energy considerations. But you would think you would come up with the same wave equation and you are just taking two different approaches. Yet you do not. Schrodinger's equation does not include a second derivative with respect to time at all!  So, you are in both cases developing the equation of a wave. Both equations are expressing the amplitude in terms of time and space propagation. Why do you end up with different equations? What is the interpretation< the meaning?

Thanks for the excellent and detailed comment.  Unfortunately I'm not familiar with the energy approach to deriving the wave equation.  That being said, in my experience when applying the energy method to conservative systems such as this, they usually arrive at the same result.  I'll take your word for it that it is different but if so, that is indeed surprising.

due to assumptions stated, does this equation not work for strings with "large" deflections like the demonstration in your previous video?

Ashwyn, that is a great question.  If the deflections are large, some of the assumptions do not hold true so the solution we obtain may no longer be accurate.  Depending on the desired fidelity of the model, this may or may not be acceptable to you.  Of course, there are many other large assumptions we make when building the model so it is important to realize that this is just a mathematical approximation of the system.  A system with large deflections will likely still display some of the characteristics predicted by the model.

This was such a needlessly complicated way to derive the 1D Wave Equation. You could have simply taken the sum of both vertical tension components and tended the sum towards the limit of delta(x) -> 0. You'd get the formal definition of a partial derivative to describe tension and be able to skip 10 minutes of convoluted trigonometry. Missing stuff like this demonstrates a lack of actual understanding to the laws you're applying - you've clearly just blunt force memorized the most complicated explanation from a Real Analysis textbook.

QUESTION:
Chris, when solving for the tension vector in the vertical direction around timestamp 17:00, it seems like the tension in the vertical direction should be 0 by inspection, right? No further free bodies or equations required. You previously drew on the assumption that alpha and beta angles are very small in order to say that the horizontal components of T are equal. Since the alpha and beta angles are very small, you stated that cosine(small angle) = 1. By that argument, i would claim that sine(small angle) = 0, making the vertical component of T = 0 by obvious inspection. I haven't finished the video yet, so maybe you address this soon, but at the moment i am pretty confused about the seemingly conflicting information.

After finishing the video, we never simplified the equation by claiming that the vertical component of T, (or T*sine(small angle)) was equal to zero. Can you elaborate?

Seth, let me know if this still seems off by the end of the video.  If so, perhaps we should set up a time to talk as I think it would be easier to talk over teleconference rather than YouTube comments since your question is a bit more involved.
@ChristopherLum I have this same question and watching the whole video didn't resolve it.

@issarice The best way to formalize this step is by considering the taylor series of sine and cosine and retain only the lowest order terms in the angle. For the cosine is one and for cosine is the angle itself.

The remaning terms are negligible comparing to these ones. For cosine we would have 1 + (small_angle^2 )/2 + ... , for sine small_angle. Now notice that small_angle^2  is much smaller than small_angle. like 0.001^2 = 0.000001 <<0.001
‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†@firemaniac100nice argument, there is a small mistake in the first part of the explanation though, it should be -> For the cosine is one and for the sine is the angle itself.

this proof, as well as others, is making a lot of assumptions that I don't really like. Here's one that you make at 15:45 - mass = density * deltaX. If the PQ segment were horizontal, that would be true, but it's not

deltaX in my opinion should be written as dx at first place, implying that it's a difference that is infinitesimally small. In that case you can make an "infinitely correct" approximation by claiming that it's horizontal in given interval (dx). This is what calculus is all about.

Nice derivation. I have a question though.You end up with a proportionality between the second derivatives with respect to time and space. Your approach is geometrical and you are looking for the wave equation as an expression for the amplitude. On the other hand if you derive the Schrodinger equation (also a wave equation) and in this case you are also modeling the amplitude of a wave albeit with special interpretations. Instead of a geometric approach, the Schrodinger  equation derives from energy considerations. But you would think you would come up with the same wave equation and you are just taking two different approaches. Yet you do not. Schrodinger's equation does not include a second derivative with respect to time at all!  So, you are in both cases developing the equation of a wave. Both equations are expressing the amplitude in terms of time and space propagation. Why do you end up with different equations? What is the interpretation< the meaning?

Thanks for the excellent and detailed comment.  Unfortunately I'm not familiar with the energy approach to deriving the wave equation.  That being said, in my experience when applying the energy method to conservative systems such as this, they usually arrive at the same result.  I'll take your word for it that it is different but if so, that is indeed surprising.

@ChristopherLum Thanks for the quick reply. Both solutions cannot be equivalent so I would like to have a deeper understanding as to why they are different. You are a smart guy and I know you could figure it out and explain it clearly. I can do this on my own but I would think you would find this interesting. due to assumptions stated, does this equation not work for strings with "large" deflections like the demonstration in your previous video?

Ashwyn, that is a great question.  If the deflections are large, some of the assumptions do not hold true so the solution we obtain may no longer be accurate.  Depending on the desired fidelity of the model, this may or may not be acceptable to you.  Of course, there are many other large assumptions we make when building the model so it is important to realize that this is just a mathematical approximation of the system.  A system with large deflections will likely still display some of the characteristics predicted by the model.

One another question is during the derivation of the wave equation small oscillation assumption was made but animation involves quite large deflections. Is it not a contradiction ? Or how should we interpret this?

Good observation.  We obtain large deflections in the numerical simulation purely because we used somewhat unrealistic constants for the problem.  If you use realistic values for tension (T) or linear density (rho) you will obtain deflections that are indeed small compared to the length of the string.  However, the unrealistic values we use do not affect the concepts/framework of the solution process, they are merely convenient to numerically simulate.
Thanks professor Please keep up the good work
Thanks for the very informative video. Can the demonstrations you made be done in the MATLAB as easy as in Mathhematica?

Matlab has the "Symbolic Math Toolbox" that will allow you to do symbolic manipulations similar to Mathematica.  Alternatively, if you have numerical values for your problem then you can do it in Matlab just as easily as Mathematica.  I like to use Mathematica for symbolic manipulation and problem setup/analysis and then use Matlab for the actual numerical solution/simulation of the problem.

I think you have a mismatch in the units...what you define as the velocity vector (J/sec)
is basically the heat flux vector at a point with units  (J/sec*m^2)
and 
q=-k*grad(u)
J/sec*K*m^2 = -(J/sec*K*m)*(K/m)

AE 501: Hi Professor Lum, at 28:00, you say that the integrand has to be 0, I don't understand why. I believe the triple integral has to equal to 0 and that the integrand can be 0, but not necessarily. Great video, thanks for bringing heat transfer to this class.

The integral could be zero without the integrand being so, depending on what surface you choose. But since the surface of the region is arbitrary, that means it only depends on the integrand for that purpose, hence the result on the video.

If material is not homogenous, do you just do piecewise solutions?
That is a good idea.  You could definitely use piecewise solutions as long as you were careful about handling boundary conditions where the materials interfaced.
If heat is produced or dissipated, it is simply adding an extra term?
what cases can have  v != k gradT?

Good question.  One situation could be if the material was not homogeneous.  For example if you had an insulator next to a conductor.  There might be a large temperature differential (AKA large gradT) but there would be no heat flow into the insulator.

[AE 501] 4:59
Just to clarify, the 1D heat problem in the last video was not a steady state solution. We assumed we had an initial temperature gradient across the bar and then it was changing with time. Whereas this case, we are just trying to determine the temperature gradient in a spatial sense but the temperature does not vary with the time.

Right, be careful as the 1D moniker refers to 1 spatial dimension.  There was a temporal dimension so there were 2 independent variables, thereby creating a PDE.  In the HW we examine a steady state solution so there is no temporal dimension but there are 2 spatial dimensions so in terms of number of independent variables, the two systems are similar.

AE501:
Professor Lum, similar to in your one dimensional video, I am confused about the assumptions made regarding small angle approximations when summing vertical forces. REF timestamp 17:30.
You noted that since theta was small, we could assume that the Cos(small angle) = 1, and as a result, the horizontal forces cancel out. By that logic it seems to me like a similar argument could be made to the vertical forces such that SIN(small angle) = 0, meaning that the vertical forces would also cancel out and the sum of the forces in the vertical direction = 0. Am I missing something?
Hi Seth, the small angle approximation is that cos(theta) =1 and sin(theta) = theta.  You can see why if you plot sin and cos and look at the functions at small values of theta.
@ChristopherLum Okay yes, that makes sense. Thanks.
@ChristopherLum I am also confused about how density * area = mass. Typically we see density * volume = mass but in this lecture it looks like we have density * delta x * delta y = mass.
@sethwhittington28 In this case we define density as mass per unit area.  You are correct that this is non-standard but is how the problem is setup.
@ChristopherLum okay yeah I thought you might be doing something along those lines.. thanks for the response.

AE501: Since the math for Maclaurin series is always simpler than a Taylor series, why would anyone use a Taylor over a Maclaurin? You can always just use more terms to get a good enough approximation.

Also, thanks, for a great term. Happy holidays!

Beni, good observation.  However in many situations you are at a specific point other than the origin and you will need to approximate the function at this location.  As such, it is actually better to just learn the Taylor Series as the Maclaurin is just a special case of the Taylor Series.

AE501:
I wasn't aware that a function is non-linear if it does not cross through the origin. You alluded to this in the lecture, but didn't expand on it and it was pretty big news to me. Is there anything more to this?

Seth, this is a common place of confusion.  y = m*x+b is not linear.  It is affine.  y = m*x is linear.  The non-zero y-intercept is what changes a mapping/function/transformation from being linear to affine.
@ChristopherLum I'm confused as to what actually linearity is. Like if we go by standard definition then both of them are linear aren't they? Could you please help me out here?

I will try this.  I have tried many different versions of GD.  None of them are very good when the "terrain" gets rough or the path to them minimum is very crooked.   I didn't like the first part of the video because there was too much time wasted writing on a white board.  I also think it would be faster to simply make a small step and keep stepping in the same direction as long as the MSE keep dropping.
I have some test data that is very difficult for GD to minimize.   There are 5 parameters, and the "terrain" is more like the Colorado river cutting and winding its way through the Grand Canyon.  The path is very narrow and always changing.   I don't have high hope for the this  Armijo algorithm.   I have found the brute force line search along with the coordinate search work best.  All methods work well if the "terrain" is like a bowl.    Nelder-Mead would be MUCH faster than the GD with Armijo.   Levenberg-Marquardt is faster yet even with the Grand Canyon like terrain of my test data.
